node.title: The Mixologists Who Create ‘Liquid Adventures’ for Couples
node.description: Josh Rosenthal, who with his wife runs Los Angeles-based Grand Bevy Corporation, says that these days the wedding cocktail is more than just a drink.

node.title: Drugmakers Handed First Win Out of Thousands of National Opioid Crisis Lawsuits
node.description: Over 3,300 lawsuits have been filed across the U.S. over an opioid epidemic that led to nearly 500,000 overdose deaths between 1999 and 2019.

node.title: Kabul Military Hospital Attacked for Second Time in Five Years, Leaving Over a Dozen Dead
node.description: The assault began with a suicide bombing at the front entrance, followed by gunmen swarming into the building.

node.title: Medicare Expansion, Free College Among Voters' Top Priorities, But Cut From Biden's Plan
node.description: Adding dental and vision benefits to Medicare was one of the most critical aspects of the original Build Back Better plan for 52 percent of voters surveyed.

node.title: Climate change's impact on crops could be felt as early as 2030
node.description: By the end of the century, corn crop yields could are projected to decrease by 24% under a high greenhouse gas emissions scenario — a decline that could have "severe implications worldwide."

node.title: Police officers admit sharing photos of murdered sisters online
node.description: Bibaa Henry and Nicole Smallman were found dead in bushes in Fryent Country Park in Wembley Park, northwest London, last year.

node.title: "Indians" sign removed as MLB team starts rebranding
node.description: The team's rebranding hit a snag last week when a roller derby team accused them of stealing their name.

node.title: CDC advisers to vote on Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine for kids 5 to 11
node.description: The CDC director will have the final word on whether to allow use of the shots for younger children.

node.title: Kristy Swanson, Actress and Vaccine Skeptic, Is Hospitalized With Covid
node.description: The actress, who played the titular character in the 1992 film “Buffy the Vampire Slayer,” said she had pneumonia.

node.title: Opioid Makers Win Major Victory in California Trial
node.description: In one of the first cases to be brought against drug manufacturers over the crisis, a judge ruled that there was “simply no evidence” the companies were liable in the epidemic.

node.title: (Very) Adult Animation About Mixed-Up Kids
node.description: In a rising tide of animated series, Netflix’s “Big Mouth,” Funimation’s “Sonny Boy” and HBO Max’s “Ten Year Old Tom” are worth catching.

node.title: Election Day 2021 Live Updates: Polls Open For Virginia, New Jersey Governor Races
node.description: The governor's race in Virginia could indicate where the country stands heading into the 2022 midterm elections. Follow Newsweek's liveblog for all the latest.

node.title: How saving soggy peat bogs can help fight climate change
node.description: Spongy, decaying vegetation around the world has safely stored carbon dioxide for centuries, but it's losing ground. But the real value of the sodden peat is finally being recognized.

node.title: Yahoo Ends Service in China Due to 'Challenging' Environment
node.description: Having slowly wound down its services over the past decade, Yahoo officially left the Chinese market on Sunday.

node.title: As Demand for Green Energy Grows, Solar Farms Face Local Resistance
node.description: Developers say industrial-scale farms are needed to meet the nation’s climate goals, but locals are fighting back against what they see as an encroachment on their pastoral settings.

node.title: Kaepernick compares treatment of players at NFL combine to slavery
node.description: Kaepernick described how pro hopefuls are treated at the combine, where prospects undergo physical and mental tests in front of team coaches and executives.

node.title: Division led Biden officials to embrace Trump-era border policies
node.description: Infighting between those who support tougher enforcement and those who favor expanding access to the asylum system has hindered the administration's border policy, officials told CBS News.

node.title: The Unequal Toll of Covid-19 in California
node.description: During Día de Muertos, or Day of the Dead, we remember those who have been lost.

node.title: Elon Musk says Tesla has not signed a deal with Hertz yet.
node.description: Hertz had said that it would convert more than 20 percent of its rental fleet to Tesla’s cars, a deal that helped propel Tesla’s stock value beyond $1 trillion for the first time.

node.title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
node.description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.

node.title: What’s Emerging From the Melting Ice?
node.description: As global temperatures rise, permafrost and glaciers are rapidly thawing and eroding, releasing ancient animal remains and human artifacts.

node.title: How Esperanza Spalding and Wayne Shorter Realized His Dream: an Opera
node.description: “Iphigenia,” an update of the ancient Greek myth eight years in the making and decades in the dreaming, will begin a run of performances this month.

node.title: NASA's SpaceX Crew-3 Launch Date Changed Again After Astronaut's 'Medical Issue'
node.description: The mission marks the first ever spaceflight for three of the crew members who will be onboard the ISS-bound Crew Dragon spacecraft.

node.title: More same-sex couples may be eligible for Social Security survivor benefits.
node.description: Even after winning the right to marry across the U.S. more than six years ago, some same-sex couples have faced challenges accessing certain benefits.

node.title: New blood test can spot more than 50 types of cancer
node.description: Many of them are hard to detect early. One doctor calls the test "a game changer."

node.title: Yahoo to exit China, citing commitment to "open" internet

node.title: Huma Abedin on overcoming her husband Anthony Weiner's betrayals
node.description: In her first TV interview, the longtime aide to Hillary Clinton talks about weathering public scandal as the wife of disgraced former Congressman Anthony Weiner, and opens up about how her anger over his sexting transgressions "almost killed me."

node.title: GOP looks for upset in New Jersey governor's race as Democrats hope to buck history
node.description: The Garden State has been reliably blue in presidential and U.S. Senate elections, but an incumbent Democrat hasn't been reelected since 1977.

node.title: New York’s 5 ballot measures include proposals to make voting easier.

node.title: Video of Virginia Man Unsure About Critical Race Theory Watched 3.5M Times

node.title: Ecuador says it will extend protections around the Galápagos Islands.

node.title: Internet Backs Man Evicting His Girlfriend After She Kicked His Cat Out

node.title: Alien Life Could Be Found on Mars Thanks to NASA Curiosity Rover's New Trick

node.title: He Ran the First N.Y.C. Marathon. Next Week, He’ll Run the 50th.

node.title: New figures reveal almost 400 healthcare workers across SA are refusing to be vaccinated against COVID-19
node.description: Almost 400 South Australian health sector workers have been forced to take leave after refusing to be vaccinated against COVID-19, according to figures released by SA Health.

node.description: Josh Hall started his hike with his dog named Happy at a trailhead near Nederland, and his cellphone pinged near the Continental Divide Trail.

node.title: Tentative win for drug makers in Calif. governments' opioids suit

node.title: Jim Jones Warned Leo Ryan's Visit Would be a 'Grave Mistake'
node.description: Jim Jones knew Congressman Ryan's visit could ruin Jonestown. "We prefer death to this kind of harassment," he told officials.

node.title: Beds and medical services cut as Queensland hospital workers defy COVID-19 vaccination mandate
node.description: Of the state's 108,000 Hospital and Health Services workers, 3,830 — or 3.54 per cent — have provided no evidence of a COVID-19 vaccination and are not on leave, forcing cuts to surgical, medical and mental health beds, Queensland Health data obtained by the ABC shows.

node.title: Dozens feared trapped after deadly collapse of high-rise in Nigeria

node.description: Environmentalists say the pledge is too little too late, and "the climate and the natural world can't afford this deal."

node.title: How to Keep a Journal
node.description: Try to establish a routine. Sometimes it helps to give yourself a prompt.

node.title: Does Life Imitate Art or Is It the Other Way Around?
node.description: In her new novel, “Still Life,” Sarah Winman delves into four decades’ worth of truth and beauty.

node.title: They Were Looking for a Place With an Elevator. They Found a Lot More.
node.description: For one Brooklyn couple, an online search for elevator buildings turned up something they had no idea they wanted: a single-family home.

node.description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on responding to infidelity.

node.description: In Uwem Akpan’s debut novel, “New York, My Village,” a Black African editor traces tribalism at home and abroad.

node.description: “We,” by Yevgeny Zamyatin, transports us to an authoritarian society governed by technological efficiency.

node.title: How Scribbling in the Margins Transformed My Reading
node.description: This grounding practice changed me from a passive reader into a thinker among other thinkers.

node.title: Dexter Always Gets His Man. Even When It’s Michael C. Hall
node.description: The star of Showtime’s gruesome hit “Dexter” returns after eight years to the serial killer who never stopped pursuing him.

node.title: Caught Between Worlds? So Are the Characters in These Books.
node.description: Three new historical novels introduce us to characters who can’t be in two places at once.

node.title: The Manhattan ‘Madam’ Who Hobnobbed With the City’s Elite
node.description: A new biography by Debby Applegate recounts the story of Polly Adler, who arrived in America from Russia at 13 and became New York’s most successful brothel owner, befriending mobsters, policemen, politicians and writers.

node.title: The Secret 53-Year-Old British Case That Could Have Legalized Trans Identity
node.description: “The Hidden Case of Ewan Forbes,” by Zoë Playdon, investigates a long-suppressed legal case involving an aristocratic Scotsman, who, raised, at least initially, as a girl, went to court to prove his male gender.

node.title: Lincoln Broke Our Constitution. Then He Remade It.
node.description: He turned a messy, pragmatic compromise into an aspirational blueprint for a nation based on equal liberty for all.

node.title: Can Specific Foods or Diets Boost Your Testosterone Levels?
node.description: What you eat or drink may affect levels of the male sex hormone, but whether a diet can increasej libido or energy depends on many things.

node.title: She Was an Organist for the Ages
node.description: Jeanne Demessieux, born 100 years ago, was an astonishing player and a virtuosic composer.
